revision.comment: synoptic scenario
revision.text:
'''Anticyclonic rotation''' or '''circulation''' is movement in the direction opposite to the Earth's rotation. In the attached video an example of an anticyclonic couplet to a supercell is documented. Note that while the supercell itself is rotating in a cyclonic direction, the couplet is forced into an anticyclonic rotation due to the [[forward flank downdraft]] and [[Inflow (meteorology)|inflow]] intersecting. Antiyclones on the synoptic scale are more often associated with higher pressure in relation to low pressure cyclones.
*''Compare: [[cyclonic rotation]]''
==External links== *[http://amsglossary.allenpress.com/glossary/search?id=anticyclonic-rotation1 Anticyclonic Rotation] - AMS Glossary of Meteorology [[Category:Climate patterns]]
{{climate-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox Government agency | agency_name = Australian Energy Market Commission | nativename = | logo = | logo_width = | logo_caption = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | formed = 2005 | dissolved = | superseding = | jurisdiction = | headquarters = | employees = | budget = | chief1_name = | chief1_position = | parent_agency = | website = {{URL|https://www.aemc.gov.au}} | footnotes = }}
The '''Australian Energy Market Commission (AEMC)'' was set up by the [[Council of Australian Governments]] through the [[Ministerial Council on Energy]] in 2005. The AEMC was established by the ''Australian Energy Market Commission Establishment Act 2004'' (SA),<ref>''[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/sa/consol_act/aemcea2004510/ Australian Energy Market Commission Establishment Act 2004]'' (SA)</ref> and commenced in July 2005. The Commission consists of one full-time and two part-time Commissioners. Two Commissioners are appointed by the participating State and Territory jurisdictions and one Commissioner is appointed by the Commonwealth.
In 2008, the AEMC completed a review of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]'s and [[South Australia]]'s retail gas and electricity markets.<ref name="repc">{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/03/01/2177099.htm?site=victoria |title=Remove electricity price controls: review |date=1 March 2008 |work=ABC Local |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=7 February 2011 }}</ref><ref name="roe">{{cite web|url=http://www.aemc.gov.au/Market-Reviews/Completed/Review-of-the-Effectiveness-of-Competition-in-Electricity-and-Gas-Retail-Markets-in-South-Australia.html |title=Review of the Effectiveness of Competition in Electricity and Gas Retail Markets in South Australia |date=18 December 2008 |publisher=Australian Energy Market Commission |accessdate=7 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218145218/http://www.aemc.gov.au/Market-Reviews/Completed/Review-of-the-Effectiveness-of-Competition-in-Electricity-and-Gas-Retail-Markets-in-South-Australia.html |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> In both states it was found that competition in the market was adequate for [[deregulation]]. The authority is also involved in inter-regional [[Electricity retailing|electricity price]]s and access issues.
==National Electricity Market== {{main|National Electricity Market}} The AEMC has two roles in relation to the National Electricity Market - as rule maker and as a provider of advice to Ministers on how best to develop energy markets over time. The AEMC actively considers market development when it considers rule change proposals, policy advice and energy market reviews. These rules are binding on the Australian energy market and enforced by the [[Australian Energy Regulator]].
==National Gas Law== The ''National Gas (South Australia) Act 2008'' introduced the National Gas Law (NGL) which commenced in all jurisdictions except Western Australia on 1 July 2008 (replacing the Gas Pipelines Access Law).
The National Gas Rules cover gas transmission and distribution in all participating Australian jurisdictions are developed and maintained by the AEMC. The AEMC is responsible for rule making, market development and policy advice concerning access to natural gas pipelines services and elements of the broader natural gas markets. This is narrower in scope than for the National Electricity Market.
==AEMC Commissioners== Since its establishment in 2005, the AEMC Commissioners have been:
* John Tamblyn - Chairman and Commissioner (2005-2010) * Ian Woodward - Commissioner; Chairman of AEMC Audit Committee; Chair Reliability Panel (2005 - 2010) * Liza Carver - Commissioner (2005 - 2008) * John Ryan - Acting Commissioner (2008 - 2009) * Neville Henderson (2010-2018)
The current Commissioners are:<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.aemc.gov.au/About-Us/About-the-AEMC/Chair-comissioners|publisher=Australian Energy Market Commission|title=Chair and Commissioners|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140620024847/http://aemc.gov.au/About-Us/About-the-AEMC/Chair-comissioners|archivedate=20 June 2014}}</ref> * [[John Pierce (public servant)|John Pierce]] - Chairman and Commissioner (appointed 2010) * Brian Spalding - Commissioner, Chair Reliability Panel (appointed 2010) * Allison Warburton (appointed 2018) * Charles Popple (appointed 2018)
==See also== {{Portal|Australia}} * [[Australian Energy Market Operator]] * [[Australian Energy Regulator]] * [[Energy policy of Australia]] * [[National Electricity Market]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.aemc.gov.au/}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Caspian coast in Hovsan, Azerbaijan.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Caspian Sea]] coast in [[Hovsan]].]] The '''water bodies of [[Azerbaijan]]''' were formed over a long geological timeframe and changed significantly throughout that period. This is particularly evidenced by remnants of ancient rivers found throughout the country. The country's water systems are continually changing under the influence of natural forces and human introduced industrial activities. Artificial rivers ([[canals]]) and [[pond]]s are a part of Azerbaijan's water systems.
The [[hydrography]] of Azerbaijan basically belongs to the [[Caspian Sea basin]].<ref name="landcomm">{{cite web|title=Inland waters |url=http://www.dtxk.gov.az/azerbaijan/nature/nature08_e.html |publisher=[[State Land and Cartography Committee (Azerbaijan)]] |accessdate=11 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714182957/http://www.dtxk.gov.az/azerbaijan/nature/nature08_e.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Rivers== [[File:caspianseamap.png|thumb|300px|A map of the [[Caspian Sea]] [[drainage basin]] to which all [[river]]s in Azerbaijan flow to.]] [[File:Kurarivermap.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kur]] and [[Aras River|Aras]] are the longest rivers of Azerbaijan and their drainage basin covers most of the country.]] [[Image:Jolfa-Aras2.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Aras River|Araz River]] along the [[Iran]]ian border with [[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic|Nakhchivan]], [[Azerbaijan]].]] Rivers form the principal part of the water systems of Azerbaijan. There are 8,359 rivers of various lengths within Azerbaijan. Of them 8,188 rivers are less than {{convert|25|km|mi}} long. Only 24 rivers are over {{convert|100|km|mi}} long.
The largest rivers that flow through the country are:<ref name="minecol">{{cite web|title=Rivers, Lakes and Reservoirs of Azerbaijan Republic|url=http://www.eco.gov.az/en/hid-chay-gol-suanbar.php|publisher=[[Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources (Azerbaijan)]]|accessdate=11 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140702101035/http://www.eco.gov.az/en/hid-chay-gol-suanbar.php|archivedate=2 July 2014|df=}}</ref> * [[Kura (Caspian Sea)|Kür]], main water source and the artery of the country<ref name="minecol"/> * [[Aras River|Araz]] * [[Alazani|Qanıx]], located in Alazan * [[Iori River|Qabırlı]], also known as Iori * [[Khrami River|Khrami]] * [[Samur River|Samur]] * [[Pirsaat River|Pirsaatçay]] * [[Bolgar-Chay]], located in [[Jalilabad District (Azerbaijan)|Jalilabad District]] * [[Aghstafa River|Ağstafa]] * [[Hekeriychay]], also known as Hekeri * [[Kurekchay]] * [[Tartar river|Tərtərçay]] ** [[Ağdabançay]] ** [[Levçay]] ** [[Turağayçay]] * [[Turyan|Türyançay]] * [[Vilesh]] * [[Karkar River|Qarqarçay]]
===River system=== The rivers in Azerbaijan can be divided into three groups:<ref name="landcomm"/> #The Kur basin rivers (Qanix, Qabirri, Turyan, Agstafa, Shekir, Terter, Khachin, etc.) #The Araz basin rivers (Arpachay, Nakhchivan, Okhchu, Hekeri, Kondelenchay, etc.) #Rivers, flowing directly into the Caspian Sea (Samur, Gudyal, Velvele, Vilesh, Lenkeran, etc.)
Azerbaijan river systems are changing and evolving under the influence of various physiographic factors:<ref name="landcomm"/> climate, landscape, geological structure, soil and vegetation. The density of the river network increases, then gradually decreases later with higher altitudes. Except for the Talysh region (1.6-2.2 km/km²), the river system density is the highest (1-2 km/km²) at 1,000-2,500 kilometers, while in the area of the Talysh mountains it peaks at 1.6-2.2 km/km² at 500-1,000 km. The average density of the river system of Azerbaijan is 0.39 km/km². The density is even lower than 0.05 km/km² in the plains.
===Kura and Aras=== {{main|Kura (Caspian Sea)|l1=Kura River|Aras River}} The Kur and Aras are the longest rivers in Azerbaijan. They run through the [[Kur-Araz Lowland]]. The rivers that directly flow into the Caspian Sea, originate mainly from the north-eastern slope of the [[Greater Caucasus]] and [[Talysh Mountains]] and run along the Samur-Devechi and Lenkeran lowlands.
The Kura River basin area (86,000 km²) up to the junction with the Aras River is smaller than the Aras water basin (101,937 km²). The river is still called Kura on the junction because the water level of the Kura is twice as high as that of the Aras River.
==Lakes== [[File:Geygol.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Lake Göygöl]]]] * [[Lake Ağgöl|Ağgöl]] * [[Ajinohur]] * [[Boyuk Alagol|Alagöl]] * [[Lake Boyukshor|Boyukshor]] * [[Lake Göygöl|Göygöl]] * [[Lake Hajikabul|Hajikabul]] * [[Jandari Lake|Jandari]] * [[Maral-gol]] * [[Masazirgol]] * [[Lake Sarysu|Sarysu]], the largest lake by area and volume<ref name="minecol"/>
==Reservoirs== [[File:Mingachevir Reservoir, Azerbaijan.JPG|thumb|300px|[[Mingachevir Reservoir]] seen from space.]] Over 60 water reservoirs have been constructed in order to regulate the river flow in Azerbaijan. The formation of these reservoirs is one of the measures that has been undertaken in order to ration the utilization of water and energy resources.
The largest water reservoirs are: * [[Agstafachay reservoir|Agstafachay]] * [[Araz reservoir|Araz]] * [[Jeyranbatan reservoir|Jeyranbatan]] * [[Khanbulanchay reservoir|Khanbulanchay]] * [[Mingachevir reservoir|Mingachevir]], the largest reservoir by area<ref name="minecol"/> * [[Sarsang reservoir|Sarsang]] * [[Shamkir reservoir|Shamkir]] * [[Varvara reservoir|Varvara]] * [[Vileshchay reservoir|Vileshchay]] * [[Yenikend reservoir|Yenikend]]
The reservoirs in Azerbaijan are designed to be utilized for various purposes, while most other ponds are used exclusively for irrigation.
==See also== * [[Environment of Azerbaijan]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commonscat|Bodies of water in Azerbaijan}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140702102418/http://www.eco.gov.az/en/hid-eti.php Scientific-Research Institute for Hydrometeorology]

revision.text:
The term '''building engineering physics''' was introduced in a report released in January 2010 commissioned by The Royal Academy of Engineering. The report, entitled ''Engineering a Low Carbon Built Environment: The Discipline of Building Engineering Physics'', presents the initiative of many at the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]] in developing a field that addresses our [[fossil fuel]] dependence while working towards a more sustainably built environment for the future.
The field of building engineering physics combines the existing professions of building services engineering, [[applied physics]] and building construction engineering into a single field designed to investigate the energy efficiency of old and new buildings.<ref>King p.8.</ref> The application of building engineering physics allows the construction and renovation of high performance, energy efficient buildings, while minimizing their environmental impacts.<ref>Sutton</ref>
Building engineering physics addresses several different areas in building performance including: air movement, thermal performance, control of moisture, ambient energy, acoustics, light, climate and biology.<ref>King pp. 8–9.</ref> This field employs creative ways of manipulating these principal aspects of a building’s indoor and outdoor environments so that a more eco-friendly standard of living is obtained. Building engineering physics is unique from other established applied sciences or engineering professions as it combines the sciences of architecture, engineering and human biology and physiology. Building engineering physics not only addresses energy efficiency and building sustainability, but also a building's internal environment conditions that affect the comfort and performance levels of its occupants.<ref>King p. 8.</ref>
Throughout the 20th century, a large percentage of buildings were constructed completely dependent on fossil fuels. Rather than focusing on energy efficiency, architects and engineers were more concerned with experimenting with “new materials and structural forms” to further aesthetic ideals.<ref>King p. 10.</ref> Now in the 21st century, building energy performance standards are pushing towards a zero carbon standard in old and new buildings alike. The threat of global change and the need for energy independence and sustainability has prompted governments across the globe to adopt firm carbon reducing standards. A significant way to meet these stringent standards is in the construction of buildings that minimize environmental impacts, as well as the refurbishing of older buildings to meet carbon emission standards. The application of building engineering physics can aid in this transition to reduce energy dependent buildings, provide for the demands of a growing population and better standard of living.<ref>King p. 11.</ref> Growth in the application of this field is due in large part to the'' introduction of regulations requiring the calculation of carbon emissions to demonstrate compliance, principally the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive (EPBD)''.<ref>King p. 12.</ref>
Unfortunately, the discipline of building engineering physics is severely impaired by lack of diverse education in the construction industry. Very few in the construction industry know how to apply the principles of building engineering physics and do not have interdisciplinary experience.<ref>Sutton</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Sources== *{{cite web|url=http://www.raeng.org.uk/news/releases/shownews.htm?NewsID=542|title=Engineering a Low-Carbon Built Environment|last=Sutton|first=Jane|date=1 January 2010|publisher=Royal Academy of Engineering|accessdate=19 March 2010}} *{{cite book|last=King|first=Doug|title=Engineering a Low Carbon Build Environment: The Discipline of Building Engineering Physics|publisher=Engineering a Low Carbon Build Environment: The Discipline of Building Engineering Physics|location=London}}
[[Category:Applied and interdisciplinary physics]] [[Category:Energy conservation]] [[Category:Building engineering]] [[Category:Environmental design]] [[Category:Environmental science]]

revision.text:
{{Merge to |Carbon sequestration |date=April 2018|discuss=Talk:Carbon_sequestration#Merge_carbon_dioxide_removal_into_this?}}
'''Carbon dioxide removal''' (CDR) refers to a number of technologies, the objective of which is the large-scale removal of [[carbon dioxide]] [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere|from the atmosphere]].<ref name=RoyalSociety>{{cite web|title=Geoengineering the climate: science, governance and uncertainty|url=http://royalsociety.org/Geoengineering-the-climate/|publisher=[[The Royal Society]]|year=2009|accessdate=2011-09-10}}</ref><ref name="Negative emissions: Part 1 – research landscape and synthesis">{{Cite journal|title=Negative emissions: Part 1 – research landscape and synthesis|journal=Environmental Research Letters|volume=13|issue=6|pages=063001|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/aabf9b|year=2018|accessdate=2018-05-31|doi=10.1088/1748-9326/aabf9b|last1=Minx|first1=Jan C|last2=Lamb|first2=William F|last3=Callaghan|first3=Max W|last4=Fuss|first4=Sabine|last5=Hilaire|first5=Jérôme|last6=Creutzig|first6=Felix|last7=Amann|first7=Thorben|last8=Beringer|first8=Tim|last9=De Oliveira Garcia|first9=Wagner|last10=Hartmann|first10=Jens|last11=Khanna|first11=Tarun|last12=Lenzi|first12=Dominic|last13=Luderer|first13=Gunnar|last14=Nemet|first14=Gregory F|last15=Rogelj|first15=Joeri|last16=Smith|first16=Pete|last17=Vicente Vicente|first17=Jose Luis|last18=Wilcox|first18=Jennifer|last19=Del Mar Zamora Dominguez|first19=Maria}}</ref> Among such technologies are [[bio-energy with carbon capture and storage]], [[biochar]], [[ocean fertilization]], [[enhanced weathering]], and [[Carbon dioxide scrubber|direct air capture]] when combined with storage.<ref name=RoyalSociety /> CDR is a different approach than removing {{CO2}} from the stack emissions of large [[fossil fuel]] point sources, such as [[power station]]s. The latter reduces emission to the atmosphere but cannot reduce the amount of carbon dioxide already in the atmosphere. As CDR removes carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, it creates negative emissions, offsetting emissions from small and dispersed point sources such as domestic heating systems, airplanes and vehicle exhausts.<ref name=Vergragt>{{Cite journal | last1 = Vergragt | first1 = P.J. | last2 = Markusson | first2 = N. | last3 = Karlsson | first3 = H. | doi = 10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2011.01.020 | title = Carbon capture and storage, bio-energy with carbon capture and storage, and the escape from the fossil-fuel lock-in | journal = Global Environmental Change | volume = 21 | issue = 2 | pages = 282–92 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref><ref name=Azar>{{Cite journal | last1 = Azar | first1 = C. | last2 = Lindgren | first2 = K. | last3 = Larson | first3 = E. | last4 = Möllersten | first4 = K. | title = Carbon Capture and Storage from Fossil Fuels and Biomass – Costs and Potential Role in Stabilizing the Atmosphere | doi = 10.1007/s10584-005-3484-7 | journal = Climatic Change | volume = 74 | pages = 47–79 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> It is regarded by some as a form of [[climate engineering]],<ref name=RoyalSociety/> while other commentators describe it as a form of [[carbon capture and storage]] or extreme mitigation.<ref name=GCCSI>{{cite web|title=Global Status of BECCS Projects 2010 |url=http://cdn.globalccsinstitute.com/publications/global-status-beccs-projects-2010 |publisher=[[Biorecro]] and [[Carbon capture and storage (timeline)#Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute|The Global Carbon Capture and Storage institute]] |year=2011 |accessdate=2011-09-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928114027/http://cdn.globalccsinstitute.com/publications/global-status-beccs-projects-2010 |archivedate=2013-09-28 |df= }}</ref> Whether CDR would satisfy common definitions of "climate engineering" or "geoengineering" usually depends upon the scale on which it would be undertaken.
The likely need for CDR has been publicly expressed by a range of individuals and organizations involved with climate change issues, including [[IPCC]] chief [[Rajendra Pachauri]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/environment/article2144825.ece|title=Carbon must be sucked from air, says IPCC chief Rajendra Pachauri|last=Pagnamenta|first=Robin|date=2009-12-01|work=Times Online|accessdate=13 December 2009|location=London}}</ref> the [[UNFCCC]] executive secretary [[Christiana Figueres]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/jun/05/global-warming-suck-greenhouse-gases?intcmp=122|title=Global warming crisis may mean world has to suck greenhouse gases from air|last=Harvey|first=Fiona|date=2011-06-05|work=Guardian Online|accessdate=10 September 2011}}</ref> and the [[World Watch Institute]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.crikey.com.au/rooted/2009/01/15/negative-emissions-needed-for-a-safe-climate-world-watch-institute/|title=Negative emissions needed for a safe climate|last=Hollo|first=Tim|date=2009-01-15|accessdate=10 September 2011}}</ref> Institutions with major programs focusing on CDR include the Lenfest Center for Sustainable Energy at the [[Earth Institute|Earth Institute, Columbia University]],<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/big-idea/13/carbon-capture |title=National Geographic Magazine - NGM.com |publisher=Ngm.nationalgeographic.com |date=2013-04-25 |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref> and the Climate Decision Making Center,<ref name=CDMC>{{cite web|url=http://cdmc.epp.cmu.edu/docs/pub/co.pdf |title=Snatching Carbon Dioxide from the Atmosphere |publisher=Cdmc.epp.cmu.edu |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref> an international collaboration operated out of Carnegie-Mellon University's Department of Engineering and Public Policy.
The [[mitigation of global warming|mitigation]] effectiveness of air capture is limited by societal investment, land use, availability of geologic reservoirs, and leakage. The reservoirs are estimated to be sufficient to for storing at least 545 GtC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/special-reports/srccs/srccs_wholereport.pdf|title=Carbon dioxide capture and storage|date=2005|work=IPCC|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref> Storing 771 GtC would cause a 186 ppm atmospheric reduction.<ref name="Lenton2009">{{cite journal|title=The radiative forcing potential of different climate geoengineering options|journal=Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics|year=2009|first=TM|last=Lenton|author2=NE Vaughan|volume=9|issue=15|pages=2559–608|url= http://www.atmos-chem-phys-discuss.net/9/2559/2009/acpd-9-2559-2009.html|doi=10.5194/acp-9-5539-2009}}</ref> In order to return the atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> content to 350 ppm we need atmospheric reduction of 50 ppm plus an additional 2 ppm per year of current emissions.
== General == Carbon dioxide removal is different from reducing emissions, as the former produces an outlet of carbon dioxide from [[Earth's atmosphere]], whereas the latter decreases the inlet of [[Carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere|carbon dioxide to the atmosphere]]. Both have the same net effect, but for achieving carbon dioxide concentration levels below present levels, carbon dioxide removal is critical. Also for meeting higher concentration levels, carbon dioxide removal is increasingly considered to be crucial as it provides the only possibility to fill the gap between needed reductions to meet [[Climate change mitigation|mitigation targets]] and [[:File:Global Warming Observed CO2 Emissions from fossil fuel burning vs IPCC scenarios.jpg|global emission trends]].
In the ''[[OECD]] Environmental Outlook to 2050'' released at the [[2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference]], the authors commented on the need for negative emissions, stating "Achieving lower concentration targets (450 ppm) depends significantly on the use of [[BECCS]]".
A [[carbon dioxide sink]] such as a concentrated group of plants or any other primary producer that binds [[carbon dioxide]] into biomass, such as within forests and [[kelp bed]]s, is not carbon negative, as sinks are not permanent. A carbon dioxide sink of this type moves [[carbon]], in the form of carbon dioxide, from the atmosphere or hydrosphere to the biosphere. This process could be undone, for example by [[wildfire]]s or [[logging]].
Carbon dioxide sinks that store carbon dioxide in the Earth's crust by [[Geologic sequestration of CO2|injecting it into the subsurface]], or in the form of insoluble [[carbonate]] salts ([[Carbon capture and storage#Mineral storage|mineral sequestration]]), are considered carbon negative. This is because they are removing carbon from the atmosphere and [[Carbon sequestration|sequestering]] it indefinitely and presumably for a considerable duration (thousands to millions of years). However, Carbon Capture technology remains, at best, theoretical and is yet to reach more than 33% efficiency. Furthermore, this process could be rapidly undone, for example by [[earthquake]]s or [[mining]].
==Methods==
===Bio-energy with carbon capture & storage=== {{Main|Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage}} Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage, or BECCS, uses biomass to extract carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, and carbon capture and storage technologies to concentrate and permanently store it in deep geological formations.
BECCS is currently (as of October 2012) the only CDR technology deployed at full industrial scale, with 550 000 tonnes CO<sub>2</sub>/year in total capacity operating, divided between three different facilities (as of January 2012).<ref name="Global Status of BECCS Projects 2010">{{cite web |title=Global Status of BECCS Projects 2010 |url=http://www.globalccsinstitute.com/publications/global-status-beccs-projects-2010/online/27026 |publisher=Biorecro AB, Global CCS Institute |year=2010 |accessdate=2012-01-20 }}</ref><ref name="ECN Global Technology Roadmap">{{cite web |title=Global Technology Roadmap for CCS in Industry Biomass-based industrial CO<sub>2</sub> sources: biofuels production with CCS |url=http://www.ecn.nl/docs/library/report/2011/e11012.pdf |publisher=ECN |year=2011 |accessdate=2012-01-20 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sequestration.org/resources/topStories.html |title= First U.S. large demonstration-scale injection of CO<sub>2</sub> from a biofuel production facility begins |accessdate=20 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gctelegram.com/News/ethanol-plant-carbon-sequestration-3-13-10 |title=Ethanol plant to sequester CO<sub>2</sub> emissions |accessdate=20 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310195823/http://www.gctelegram.com/News/ethanol-plant-carbon-sequestration-3-13-10 |archivedate=10 March 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ksallink.com/?cmd=displaystory&story_id=2504&format=print |title= Production Begins at Biggest Ethanol Plant in Kansas |accessdate=20 January 2012}}</ref>
The [[Imperial College London]], the UK [[Met Office]] [[Hadley Centre for Climate Prediction and Research]], the [[Tyndall Centre for Climate Change Research]], the [http://www.walker-institute.ac.uk/ Walker Institute for Climate System Research], and the [[Grantham Institute for Climate Change]] issued a joint report on carbon dioxide removal technologies as part of the ''AVOID: Avoiding dangerous climate change'' research program, stating that "Overall, of the technologies studied in this report, [[BECCS]] has the greatest maturity and there are no major practical barriers to its introduction into today’s energy system. The presence of a primary product will support early deployment."<ref name=AVOID>{{cite web |title=The Potential for the Deployment of Negative Emissions Technologies in the UK |url=http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/avoid/files/resources-researchers/AVOID_WS2_D1_18_20100730.pdf |publisher=Grantham Institute for Climate Change, Imperial College |year=2010 |accessdate=2012-01-16 }}</ref>
According to the [[OECD]], "Achieving lower concentration targets (450 ppm) depends significantly on the use of [[BECCS]]".<ref name="OECD">[http://www.oecd.org/env/cc/49082173.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526212849/http://www.oecd.org/env/cc/49082173.pdf|date=May 26, 2013}}</ref>
===Biochar=== {{Main|Biochar}}
[[Biochar]] is created by the [[pyrolysis]] of [[biomass]], and is under investigation as a method of [[carbon sequestration]]. [[Biochar]] is a charcoal that is used for agricultural purposes which also aids in [[carbon sequestration]], the capture or hold of carbon. It is created using a process called pyrolysis, which is basically the act of high temperature heating biomass in an environment with low oxygen levels. What remains is a material known as char, similar to charcoal but is made through a sustainable process, thus the use of biomass.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is biochar?|url=http://www.biochar.ac.uk/what_is_biochar.php|website=UK Biochar research center|publisher=University of Edinburgh Kings Buildings Edinburgh|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref> Biomass is organic matter produced by living organisms or recently living organisms, most commonly plants or plant based material.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Biomass?|url=http://www.biomassenergycentre.org.uk/portal/page?_pageid=76,15049&_dad=portal|website=Biomass Energy Center|publisher=Direct.gov.uk|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref> The offset of GHG emission, if biochar were to be implemented, would be a maximum of 12%. This equates to about 106 metric tons of CO<sub>2</sub> equivalents. On a medium conservative level, it would be 23% less than that, at 82 metric tons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Climate change and Biochar|url=http://www.biochar-international.org/biochar/carbon|website=International Biochar Initiative|publisher=International Biochar Initiative|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref> A study done by the UK Biochar Research Center has stated that, on a conservative level, biochar can store 1 gigaton of carbon per year. With greater effort in marketing and acceptance of biochar, the benefit could be the storage of 5–9 gigatons per year of carbon in biochar soils.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ierm.ed.ac.uk/homes/sshackle/WP2.pdf|title=Biochar reducing and removing CO2 while improving soils: A significant sustainable response to climate change|website=UKBRC|publisher=UK Biochar research Center|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref>
===Enhanced weathering=== {{Main|Enhanced weathering}} Enhanced weathering is a chemical approach to remove carbon dioxide involving land- or ocean-based techniques. One example of a land-based enhanced weathering technique is in-situ carbonation of silicates. [[Ultramafic rock]], for example, has the potential to store from hundreds to thousands of years' worth of CO<sub>2</sub> emissions, according to estimates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.nytimes.com/www.nytimes.com/gwire/2009/03/09/09greenwire-maps-show-rocks-ideal-for-sequestering-carbon-10041.html|title=Maps show rocks ideal for sequestering carbon - NYTimes.com|website=archive.nytimes.com|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=U.S. Department of the Interior|first=|date=|title=Mapping the Mineral Resource Base for Mineral Carbon-Dioxide Sequestration in the Conterminous United States|url=https://pubs.usgs.gov/ds/414/downloads/DS414_text_508.pdf|journal=U.S. Geological Survey|volume=Data Series 414|pages=|via=}}</ref> Ocean-based techniques involve alkalinity enhancement, such as grinding, dispersing, and dissolving olivine, limestone, silicates, or calcium hydroxide to address ocean acidification and CO<sub>2</sub> sequestration. Enhanced weathering is considered one of the least expensive geoengineering options. One example of a research project on the feasibility of enhanced weathering is the [[CarbFix]] project in Iceland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalccsinstitute.com/projects/carbfix-sulfix-project|title=CarbFix Project {{!}} Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute|website=www.globalccsinstitute.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.or.is/english/carbfix/carbfix-project|title=The CarbFix Project|date=2017-08-22|work=www.or.is|access-date=2018-05-15|language=is}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/10/science/burying-a-mountain-of-co2.html|title=Turning Carbon Dioxide Into Rock, and Burying It|date=2015-02-09|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
===Direct air capture (DAC)=== Carbon dioxide can be removed from ambient air through chemical processes, sequestered, and stored. Traditional modes of carbon capture such as precombustion and postcombustion {{co2}} capture from large point sources can help slow the rate of increase of the atmospheric {{co2}} concentration, but only the direct removal of {{co2}} from the air, or “direct air capture” (DAC), can actually reduce the global atmospheric {{co2}} concentration if combined with long-term storage of {{co2}}.
A few engineering proposals have been made for removing {{co2}} from the atmosphere, but work in this area is still in its infancy. <ref name ="ReviewDAC2016">{{cite journal|last1=Sanz-Pérez|first1=E.S.|last2=Murdock|first2=C.R.|last3=Didas|first3=S.A.|last4=Jones|first4=C.W. |title=Direct Capture of {{co2}} from Ambient Air|journal=Chem. Rev. |issue=19|volume=116|year=2016|pages=11840–76|doi=10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00173|pmid=27560307}}</ref> Among the main technologies proposed, three of them stand out: [[Causticization]] with alkali and alkali-earth hydroxides,<ref>{{cite conference|last1=Lackner|first1=K.S.|last2=Ziock|first2=H.|last3=Grimes|first3=P.|title=Carbon Dioxide Extraction from Air: Is It an Option?|conference=Proceedings of the 24th Annual Technical Conference on Coal Utilization & Fuel Systems|year=1999|pages=885–896}}</ref> [[carbonation]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nikulshina|first1=V.|last2=Ayesa|first2=N.|last3=Gálvez|first3=M.E. |last4=Stainfeld|first4=A. |title=Feasibility of Na–Based Thermochemical Cycles for the Capture of {{co2}} from air. Thermodynamic and Thermogravimetric Analyses.|journal=Chem. Eng. J. |issue=1–3|volume=140|year=2016|pages=62–70|doi=10.1016/j.cej.2007.09.007}}</ref> and organic−inorganic hybrid sorbents consisting of amines supported in porous [[adsorbents]]. A 2016 article reviews the research in these various areas.<ref name="ReviewDAC2016" />
One proposed method is by so-called ''artificial trees''.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.livescience.com/technology/070501_carbon_capture.html|title=New Device Vacuums Away Carbon Dioxide|publisher= LiveScience|date=2007-05-01|accessdate=2009-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/may/31/carbonemissions.climatechange|title=Could US scientist's 'CO<sub>2</sub> catcher' help to slow warming? | Environment|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-10-29|location=London|first=David|last=Adam|date=2008-05-31}}</ref> This concept, proposed by climate scientist [[Wallace S. Broecker]] and science writer [[Robert Kunzig]],<ref>[http://www.earth.columbia.edu/articles/view/2246 Artificial trees designed by Wallace Broecker]</ref> imagines huge numbers of artificial trees around the world to remove ambient CO<sub>2</sub>. The technology is now being pioneered by [[Klaus Lackner]], a researcher at the [[Earth Institute]], [[Columbia University]],<ref>The Earth Institute, Columbia University http://www.earth.columbia.edu/sections/view/9</ref> whose artificial tree technology can suck up to 1,000 times more CO<sub>2</sub> from the air than real trees can,{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} at a rate of about one ton of carbon per day if the artificial tree is approximately the size of an actual tree.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energynow.com/video/2011/07/29/cleaning-carbon-mess-07312011# |title=Cleaning up the Carbon Mess |date=July 31, 2011 |publisher=Energy Now |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8223528.stm 'Artificial trees' to cut carbon]. Retrieved November 7, 2010.</ref> The CO<sub>2</sub> would be captured in a filter and then removed from the filter and stored.
The chemistry used is a variant of that described [[#Example CO2 scrubbing chemistry|below]], as it is based on [[sodium hydroxide]]. However, in a more recent design proposed by [[Klaus Lackner]], the process can be carried out at only 40 °C by using a [[polymer]]-based [[ion exchange resin]], which takes advantage of changes in [[humidity]] to prompt the release of captured CO<sub>2</sub>, instead of using a kiln. This reduces the energy required to operate the process.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energy.columbia.edu/?id=research_carbon_capture#air |title=Lenfest Center for Sustainable Energy |publisher=Energy.columbia.edu |accessdate=2013-09-22}}</ref>
Another substance which can be used are [[Metal-organic framework]]s (or MOF's).<ref>[https://newscenter.lbl.gov/2015/03/17/a-better-way-of-scrubbing-co2/ Scrubbing CO<sub>2</sub> with MOFs]</ref> A special MOF has been made specifically for locking CO<sub>2</sub> by Joeri Denayer.<ref>[http://www.weareparis.be/algemeen/vub-prof-joeri-denayer-stopt-de-opwarming-van-de-aarde-in-canvas-wetenschapsprogramma Wetenschap redt de wereld docu on Joeri Denayer's MOFs]</ref>
In 2008, the [[Discovery Channel]] covered<ref>[http://dsc.discovery.com/tv/project-earth/explores/carbon.html – Discovery Channel, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090119022725/http://dsc.discovery.com/tv/project-earth/explores/carbon.html |date=January 19, 2009 }}</ref> the work of [[David Keith (scientist)|David Keith]],<ref>[https://www.ucalgary.ca/~keith/AirCapture.html – David Keith] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201014040/http://www.ucalgary.ca/~keith/AirCapture.html |date=February 1, 2009 }}</ref> of [[University of Calgary]], who built a tower, 4 feet wide and 20 feet tall (1.2×6.1 meters), with a fan at the bottom that sucks air in, which comes out again at the top. In the process, about half the CO<sub>2</sub> is removed from the air.
This device uses the chemical process described in detail [[Carbon dioxide removal#Example CO2 scrubbing chemistry|below]]. The system demonstrated on the Discovery Channel was a 1/90,000th scale test system of the capture section; the reagents are regenerated in a separate facility. The main costs of a full plant will be the cost to build it, and the energy input to regenerate the chemicals and produce a pure stream of CO<sub>2</sub>.
To put this into perspective, people in the U.S. emit about 20 tonnes of CO<sub>2</sub> per person annually.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/datablog/2009/sep/02/carbon-emissions-per-person-capita|title=Carbon emissions per person, by country|last=Vaughan|first=Adam|date=2009-09-02|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref> In other words, each person in the U.S. would require a tower like the one featured by the Discovery Channel to remove this amount of CO<sub>2</sub> from the air, requiring an annual 2 megawatt-hours of electricity to operate it. By comparison, a refrigerator consumes about 1.2 megawatt-hours annually (2001 figures). A modern, A++ rated refrigerator uses about 140 Kwh annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eia.doe.gov/emeu/recs/recs2001/enduse2001/enduse2001.html|title=End-Use Consumption of Electricity by End Use and Appliance|publisher= Eia.doe.gov|accessdate=2009-10-29}}</ref> But, by combining many small systems such as this into one large system, the construction costs and energy use can be reduced.
It has been proposed that the [[Solar updraft tower]] to generate electricity from thermal air currents also be used at the same time for amine gravity scrubbing of CO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/SC0410/S00063.htm The Methane Economy]</ref> Some heat would be required to regenerate the amine.
A similar CO<sub>2</sub> scrubber has also been built by [[Carbon Engineering]]. Besides simply focusing on capturing the CO<sub>2</sub>, the company also puts emphasis on reuse of the CO<sub>2</sub>, for example in the production of fuels, which would thus be [[zero emissions|carbon-neutral]].<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/hilarybrueck/2015/07/24/this-company-wants-to-recycle-carbon-dioxide-from-the-atmosphere/ Forbes on Carbon Engineering's carbon scrubber]</ref><ref>[http://carbonengineering.com/our-technology/ More info on the co2 scrubber]</ref>
Direct air capture has been proposed as a way of generating carbon-neutral organic chemicals, by harvesting the atmospheric compounds and then using them in the production and synthesis of polymers and fuels.
The Swiss-based Climeworks built the first industrial scale direct air capturing plant in [[Hinwil]], in the canton of Zurich, Switzerland. It started up in May 2017,<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-climatechange-carbon/from-thin-air-to-stone-greenhouse-gas-test-starts-in-iceland-idUSKBN1CG2D4|title=From thin air to stone: greenhouse gas test starts in Iceland|last=Doyle|first=Alister|date=2017-10-11|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> and could scrub up to 900 metric tons of CO<sub>2</sub> per year using heat from a local waste incineration plant. The CO2 was then pumped into local [[greenhouse]]<nowiki/>s, where it was used to help grow vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fastcoexist.com/3052554/the-worlds-first-commercial-carbon-capture-plant-will-turn-pollution-into-cash?partner=rss|title=The World's First Commercial Carbon Capture Plant Will Turn Pollution Into Cash|date=2015-10-22|newspaper=Co.Exist|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-41816332|title=Climate's magic rabbit: Pulling CO2 out of thin air|last=McGrath|first=Matt|date=2017-11-15|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Climeworks and [[Orkuveita Reykjavíkur|Reykjavik Energy]] also started up a small test direct air capturing plant in [[Hellisheiði Power Station|Hellisheidi]], Iceland in October 2017. Using waste heat from a local geothermal power plant, the test plant captured up to 50 tons of CO<sub>2</sub> per year which was bound with water and injected over 700 metres underground into basaltic bedrock. The CO<sub>2</sub> reacted with the basalt to form solid carbonate minerals.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.powermag.com/test-of-carbon-capture-technology-underway-at-iceland-geothermal-plant/?mypower|title=Test of Carbon Capture Technology Underway at Iceland Geothermal Plant|last=Prroctor|first=Daryll|date=2017-12-01|work=POWER Magazine|access-date=2017-12-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Ocean fertilization=== {{Main|Ocean fertilization}}
Ocean fertilization or ocean nourishment is a type of climate engineering based on the purposeful introduction of nutrients to the upper ocean to increase marine food production and to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. A number of techniques, including fertilization by iron, urea and phosphorus have been proposed.
=== Wooden building construction ===
In their "roadmap for rapid decarbonization", Rockström et al. (2017) proposed in the journal [[Science]] that "[a]fter 2030, all building construction must be carbon-neutral or carbon-negative. The construction industry must either use emissions-free concrete and steel or replace those materials with zero- or negative-emissions substances such as wood, stone, and carbon fiber.<ref>[[Johan Rockström]], [[Owen Gaffney]], [[Joeri Rogelj]], [[Malte Meinshausen]], [[Nebojsa Nakicenovic]] and [[Hans Joachim Schellnhuber]] (2017): "A roadmap for rapid decarbonization." Science 355, no. 6331, pp. 1269-1271.</ref> Especially wooden building constructions are a promising way to store emissions, as wood mainly contains carbon, grows faster due to the higher CO2 concentration and is established as a building material for several centuries. Projects like [[W350]] in Tokyo demonstrate that even skyscrapers could potentially be built from wood and, thus, store large amounts of carbon.<ref>https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/20/worlds-tallest-wooden-skyscraper-japan.html</ref>
==Example CO<sub>2</sub> scrubbing chemistry== {{Main|Carbon dioxide scrubber}}
===Calcium oxide=== [[Calcium oxide]] (quicklime) will absorb CO<sub>2</sub> from [[Atmosphere|atmospheric air]] mixed with [[steam]] at 400 °C (forming [[calcium carbonate]]) and release it at 1,000 °C. This process, proposed by [[A. Steinfeld]], can be performed using [[renewable energy]] from thermal [[concentrated solar power]].<ref name="newscientist1">{{cite web|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20126901.200-can-technology-clear-the-air.html?full=true|title=Can technology clear the air? |publisher=[[New Scientist]]|date=2009-01-12|accessdate=2009-10-29}}</ref> Quicklime is made by heating limestone to release the {{CO2}} within it. Quicklime is mixed with sand for brick building as mortar, where it hardens by absorption of {{CO2}}.
===Sodium hydroxide=== Zeman and Lackner outlined a specific method of air capture using [[Carbon dioxide scrubber#Potassium hydroxide|sodium hydroxide]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Zeman, F.S. |author2=Lackner, K.S. |title=Capturing carbon dioxide directly from the atmosphere |journal=World Resour. Rev. |volume=16 |pages=157–72 |year=2004}}</ref> Carbon Engineering, a Calgary, Alberta firm founded in 2009 and partially funded by [[Bill Gates]], is developing a process to capture carbon dioxide using a solution of potassium hydroxide mixed with some water at their [[pilot plant]]. They hope to create and sell synthetic fuels at a cost of $100 a ton.<ref name=NYT01513>{{cite news|title=Pulling Carbon Dioxide Out of Thin Air|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/06/business/pilot-plant-in-the-works-for-carbon-dioxide-cleansing.html|accessdate=January 8, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 5, 2013|author=Anne Eisenberg}}</ref>
== Direct air capture (DAC) process example using NaOH == {{see also|carbon dioxide scrubber}} [[File:Direct Air Capture Process Flow Diagram using Caustic Soda.png|thumb|600px|Main steps in a DCA process that uses NaOH ([[caustic soda]]) as the absorber.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Zeman|first=Frank|date=2007-11-01|title=Energy and Material Balance of CO2 Capture from Ambient Air|journal=Environmental Science & Technology|volume=41|issue=21|pages=7558–63|doi=10.1021/es070874m|issn=0013-936X}}</ref>]] Among the technologies studied for direct air capture (DAC), the use of [[carbon dioxide scrubber#Sodium Hydroxide|aqueous hydroxide sorbents]] is one of the most promising approaches.<ref name="ReviewDAC2016"/> In this process, CO<sub>2</sub> from the air is chemically dissolved into NaOH(aq) solution as Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>; the Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> is then reacted with solid Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub>, which regenerates the solvent and produces CaCO<sub>3</sub> crystals; lastly, heat is applied to the CaCO<sub>3</sub> crystals to produce pure CO<sub>2</sub> gas.<ref name=":0" />
Air is pumped through the CO<sub>2</sub> absorber as the first step of this process.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Introduction to Carbon Capture and Sequestration, Vol 1|last=Berend Smit, Jeffrey A. Reimer, Curtis M. Oldenburg and Ian C. Bourg|first=|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> CO<sub>2</sub> absorber for DAC are designed either as a [[Countercurrent exchange|counter-current]] [[spray tower]] or as a counter-current [[Falling-film column|thin-falling-film contractor]] to maximize the contact area between the air and the solvent and thus maximize the absorption driving force.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> The solvent is regenerated in the causticization unit by reacting the Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> with Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub>, which also transfers the captured CO<sub>2</sub> to the form of CaCO<sub>3</sub> solid crystals.<ref name=":0" /> A mechanical filter is then used to separate the CaCO<sub>3</sub> crystals from the water.<ref name=":0" /> Since the crystals come out wet from the filter, they are dried in a steam dryer.<ref name=":0" /> Then the dry crystals are heated in a furnace to produce CaO and pure CO<sub>2</sub> gas.<ref name=":0" /> The CaO is then hydrated to regenerate the Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> used for the causticization reaction.<ref name=":0" /> The pure CO<sub>2</sub> stream is then compressed and ready to be transported for geologic sequestration, [[Enhanced oil recovery|EOR]], or other commercial applications.
1 M NaOH (aq) is a typical solvent concentration because this concentrations is limited by the causticization reaction that regenerates the solvent it is not too far from the practical maximum of 2 M NaOH.<ref name=":0" /> The furnace/kiln can be powered renewably or by burning fuel on-site with pure oxygen produces in an on-site air separation unit.
NaOH is economically competitive with other absorbents (e.g. Amines) used for DAC processes.<ref name=":0" /> DAC processes are energy intensive.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Calcination (at the furnace) is the most energy intensive step of this process.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
==Economic issues== A crucial issue for CDR methods is their cost, which differs substantially among the different technologies: some of these are not sufficiently developed to perform cost assessments. In 2011 the [[American Physical Society]] estimated the costs for direct air capture to be $600/tonne with optimistic assumptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aps.org/policy/reports/popa-reports/loader.cfm?csModule=security/getfile&PageID=244407|title=Direct Air Capture of CO<sub>2</sub> with Chemicals|publisher=[[The American Physical Society]]|date=2011-06-01|accessdate=2011-09-10}}</ref> A 2018 study found this estimate lowered to between $94 and $232 per tonne.<ref name="KeithHolmes2018">{{cite journal|last1=Keith|first1=David W.|last2=Holmes|first2=Geoffrey|last3=St. Angelo|first3=David|last4=Heidel|first4=Kenton|title=A Process for Capturing CO2 from the Atmosphere|journal=Joule|year=2018|doi=10.1016/j.joule.2018.05.006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://carbonengineering.com/climate-change-breakthrough/|title= Climate Change Breakthrough: Large-scale capture of atmospheric CO₂ shown to be feasible and affordable|date=2018-06-07}}</ref> The IEA Greenhouse Gas R&D Programme and [[Ecofys]] provides an estimate that 3.5 billion tonnes could be removed annually from the atmosphere with [[BECCS]] (Bio-Energy with Carbon Capture and Storage) at carbon prices as low as €50 per tonne,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eenews.net/assets/2011/08/04/document_cw_01.pdf|title= Potential for Biomass and Carbon Capture and Storage|publisher=IEA Greenhouse Gas R&D Programme|date=2011-07-06|accessdate= 2011-09-10}}</ref> while a report from [[Biorecro]] and the [[Carbon capture and storage (timeline)#Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute|Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute]] estimates costs "below €100" per tonne for large scale BECCS deployment.<ref name=GCCSI />
==Risks, problems and criticisms== CDR is slow to act, and requires a long-term political and engineering program to effect.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Cao | first1 = L. | last2 = Caldeira | first2 = K. | doi = 10.1088/1748-9326/5/2/024011 | title = Atmospheric carbon dioxide removal: Long-term consequences and commitment | journal = Environmental Research Letters | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 024011 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> CDR is even slower to take effect on [[Ocean acidification|acidified oceans]]. In a ''Business as usual'' [[Representative Concentration Pathways|concentration pathway]], the deep ocean will remain acidified for centuries, and as a consequence many marine species are in danger of extinction.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/nclimate2729|title=Long-term response of oceans to CO2 removal from the atmosphere|journal=Nature Climate Change|year=2015|last1=Mathesius|first1=Sabine|last2=Hofmann|first2=Matthias|last3=Caldeira|first3=Ken|last4=Schellnhuber|first4=Hans Joachim|volume=5|issue=12|pages=1107–13}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Bio-energy with carbon capture and storage]] (BECCS) * [[Biochar]] * [[Carbon capture and storage]] * [[Carbon dioxide scrubber]] * [[Carbon-neutral fuel]] * [[Climate change mitigation]] * [[Climate change mitigation scenarios]] * [[Climate engineering]] * [[Greenhouse gas removal]] * [[List of emerging technologies]] * [[Lithium peroxide]] * [[Low-carbon economy]] * [[Virgin Earth Challenge]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''China Energy Label''' ('''CEL''') is an energy consumption label for products in China, similar to the [[European Union energy label]]. Manufacturers of specified [[Consumer electronics|electronic devices]] are obligated to attach a CEL label to their goods to inform China-based consumers of the product’s [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]]. The label includes the product’s energy efficiency class (1-5) as well as information regarding its energy consumption.
== Targets == The CEL shows the level of energy consumption and, thus, the energy efficiency of a product. The CEL aims to encourage customers to buy energy efficient products.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cqc.com.cn/cms/cms/infopub/infopre.jsp?pubtype=D&pubpath=en&infoid=1312736507034722&templetid=1251363613119632&channelcode=A02310202" |publisher=China Quality Certification Center |title=Catalogue of CCC Certification |deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-08-06}}</ref> The target to increase energy efficiency and the acceptance of Chinese consumers towards energy efficient products is highly important, since China is the world's largest energy consumer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energylabel.gov.cn/en/Introduction/ChinaEnergyLabel/index.html |publisher=China Energy Label Center |title=About the "Background and Significance of the China Energy Label" Program|deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-08-08}}</ref>
== Responsible authority== Applications are to be filed at the China Energy Label Center (CELC), which is the main authority for CEL-classification.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energylabel.gov.cn/en//KeyProgramsandProjects/LeadList/detail/736.html |publisher=China Energy Label Center |title=About the "China National Lead List of Excellent Enterprises and Energy-saving Products" Program|deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-08-08}}</ref>
== Products requiring CEL == Since the introduction of China Energy Label in 2005, more than 25 product groups have become CEL-mandatory, while additional classes continually being added to the product catalogue. For every product that requires CEL, a [[GB standards|GB-Standard]] has been implemented.<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=http://www.energylabel.gov.cn/en/EnergyEfficiencyStandards/index.html |publisher=China Energy Label Center |title=About the "Energy Effciency Standards" Program|deadurl=no |accessdate=2014-08-08}}</ref>
Among the CEL mandatory products are: * Motors * Air conditioners * Refrigerators * Washing machines * Gas kettles * Water kettles * Photocopiers * Air compressors * Flat-screen televisions * Fluorescent tube<ref name="auto"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * http://www.energylabel.gov.cn/en/
[[Category:Government agencies of China]] [[Category:Energy conservation]] [[Category:Energy policy]] [[Category:Energy in China]]

revision.text:
{{short description|A large subsea formation extending north from the Alaskan margin into the Arctic Ocean}} [[File:Arctic Ocean bathymetric features.png|thumb|350px|Location of the Chukchi Plateau in the Arctic Ocean]] The '''Chukchi Plateau''' or '''Chukchi Cap''' is a large subsea formation extending north from the [[Alaskan]] margin into the [[Arctic Ocean]]. The ridge is normally covered by ice year-round, and reaches an approximate [[bathymetric]] [[prominence]] of 3,400 m with its highest point at 246 m below sea level.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|title=U.S. Law of the Sea cruise to map and sample the US Arctic Ocean margin|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/sites/default/files/publications/HEALY1202_FINAL_CRUISE%20REPORT.pdf|work=Center For Ocean and Coastal Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center, University of New Hampshire|accessdate=November 21, 2013|author2=Andrew Armstrong|page=4|date=September 28, 2012}}</ref> As a subsea ridge extending from the [[continental shelf of the United States]] north of Alaska, the Chukchi Plateau is an important feature in [[maritime law]] of the Arctic Ocean and has been the subject of significant geographic research. The ridge has been extensively mapped by the [[USCGC Healy|USCGC ''Healy'']], and by the Canadian icebreaker [[CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent|CCGS ''Louis S. St-Laurent'']] (with the ''Healy'') in 2011 and [[RV Marcus Langseth|RV ''Marcus Langseth'']], a [[National Science Foundation]] vessel operated by the [[Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory]] of [[Columbia University]].
== Geology == The cap is normally ice-covered, year-round.<ref name=USCGCHealyVoyage> {{cite web |url=http://www.hq.usace.army.mil/cepa/pubs/apr06/story17.htm |author=Marie Darling, [[Donald Perovich]] |title=CRREL scientists complete Arctic voyage of discovery |publisher=[[United States Army Corps of Engineers]] |accessdate=2007-09-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823224750/http://www.hq.usace.army.mil/cepa/pubs/apr06/story17.htm |archivedate=2007-08-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The cap lies roughly about 800 kilometres north of the [[Point Barrow]], [[Alaska]].<ref name=CanadianAmericanStrategicReview> {{cite web |url=https://www.sfu.ca/casr/id-arctic-empires-3.htm |title=United States Explores the Seabed of the Arctic Ocean: to bolster its Claims to the North's Strategic Resources |publisher=[[Canadian American Strategic Review]] |author=[[National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration]] |accessdate=2007-09-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024121840/http://www.sfu.ca/casr/id-arctic-empires-3.htm |archivedate=2007-10-24 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The area is notable because it is believed to be rich in natural resources (especially [[oil]], [[natural gas]] and [[manganese]]).
The geologic history of Arctic Ocean basins is a major source of debate among marine geophysicists. The difficulties associated with collecting marine geologic and geophysical data in this remote region has added to the debate on the tectonic history of the Arctic Ocean and the formation of its bathymetric features.
The Chukchi Borderland, which comprises the subsea region north of the Alaskan coast as well as the bathymetric highs of the Chukchi Plateau and the adjacent Northwind Ridge, is a continental fragment that is thought to have drifted from the Canadian [[continental margin]].<ref>http://www.agu.org/books/gd/v006/GD006p0045/GD006p0045.pdf</ref> The geomorphology of the region is defined by north-south trending [[normal fault]]ing<ref>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=John K.|title=The Arctic Ocean Region|year=1990|publisher=The Geology of North America|pages=337–50|editors=Grantz, Johnson, Sweeney|chapter=Chapter 19: The Chukchi Borderland}}</ref> –tectonic activity typical of [[continental rifting]].
Although there is no consensus as to the pre-rift location of the Chukchi Borderland, its tectonic migration could be attributed to an inferred [[spreading center]] indicated by a linear gravity low in the [[Canada Basin]] {{citation needed|date=April 2014}}. Sediments transported from the [[Mackenzie River]] Delta would have buried the spreading center. The Chukchi Plateau, which could have been connected to Canada in the vicinity of [[Ellesmere Island]], would have rifted along the spreading center to its current location.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Grantz|first=A.|title=Phanerozoic stratigraphy of Northwind Ridge, magnetic anomalies in the Canada basin, and the geometry and timing of rifting in the Amerasia Basin, Arctic Ocean|journal=GSA Bulletin|year=1998|volume=110|issue=6|pages=801–20|bibcode=1998GSAB..110..801G|doi=10.1130/0016-7606(1998)110<0801:PSONRM>2.3.CO;2|display-authors=etal}}</ref> A competing hypothesis suggests that the Chukchi Plateau may have once been attached to the Siberian shelf.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lawver|first=L.A.|title=Palaeogeographic and tectonic evolution of the Arctic Ocean during the Palaeozoic|journal=Geological Society of London Memoir|year=2011|volume=35|pages=61–77}}</ref>
The Chukchi Plateau also shows substantial evidence of [[pockmark (geology)|pockmarks]], which indicates subsurface [[hydrocarbon]] activity.<ref name="Baker"/>
== Law of the sea implications ==
[[File:UNCLOS extension.png|thumb|left|The Hedberg and Gardiner Lines]] Under the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]], party states may submit claims to the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf to extend its continental shelf beyond the 200-mile buffer that comprises a state’s [[exclusive economic zone]].<ref name=UN>{{cite web|title=United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/sites/default/files/publications/HEALY1202_FINAL_CRUISE%20REPORT.pdf|accessdate=November 21, 2013|page=53}}</ref> This requires that the proposed extension be a [[natural prolongation]] of the state’s continental shelf, which can be concluded through bathymetric mapping and analysis. If a state can prove that a subsea formation is a natural prolongation of its continental shelf, it must consequently locate the foot of the slope, the physical boundary between the natural prolongation and the [[abyssal plain]] of the ocean basin. The foot of the slope is then applied to two equations that inform the claim made by a state for the legal extension of its continental shelf.<ref name=UN/>
The first equation calculates the Hedberg Line, which is derived by adding 60 nautical miles to the foot of the slope of the natural prolongation. The second yields the Gardiner Line, which refers to the point at which the measurement of subsea sediment thickness is 1% of the distance back to the foot of the slope. The two formulae for deriving these values can be substituted in order to form a composite continental shelf for a coastal state that yields the most advantageous possible maritime territory extension.<ref name=UN/>
The [[United States]] has not ratified UNCLOS, although there is a concerted, bipartisan effort in [[United States Congress|Congress]] and among the various branches of the [[United States Military]] to do so.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patrick|first=Stewart|title=(Almost) Everyone Agrees: The U.S. Should Ratify the Law of the Sea Treaty|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2012/06/-almost-everyone-agrees-the-us-should-ratify-the-law-of-the-sea-treaty/258301/|work=The Atlantic|accessdate=November 22, 2013|date=June 10, 2012}}</ref> President [[Barack Obama]] also supports ratification of the treaty.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Strategy for the Arctic Region|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/docs/nat_arctic_strategy.pdf|work=The White House|page=2}}</ref> If the United States were to accede to UNCLOS, they would accrue the exclusive rights to exploit the natural resources on and under the continental shelf.<ref name=Baker>{{cite web|last=Baker|first=Betsy|title=The Arctic Continental Shelf: Science & Law in the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=minahT-ARBA|work=Institute for Social and Economic Research, University of Alaska–Anchorage|accessdate=November 21, 2013}}</ref> Some potentially extractable resources include manganese and metallic sulfides, oil, gas and gas hydrates, and sedentary species such as mollusks and clams.<ref name=Baker/>
== USCGC ''Healy'' expeditions ==
[[File:Healy Icebreaker 744.jpg|thumb|[[USCGC Healy|USCGC ''Healy'']]]] Since 2003, [[USCGC Healy|USCGC ''Healy'']] has undertaken eight expeditions to the [[Chukchi Sea]] with researchers from the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center at the [[University of New Hampshire]] and the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Law of the Sea|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/theme/law-sea|work=Center for Ocean and Coastal Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center, University of New Hampshire|accessdate=November 21, 2013}}</ref> The cruises investigated the bathymetry of the Chukchi Borderlands in order to inform discourse involving the potential ratification of UNCLOS by the U.S.
The latest cruise (HEALY-1202), lasting from 25 August to 27 September 2012, traversed 11,965 km of the Arctic Ocean and mapped about 68,600 km<sup>2</sup> of the seafloor. The ''Healy'' was equipped with multi-beam sonar devices and seismic measurement devices, and was manned by a 34-person scientific party and around 100 [[US Coast Guard]]smen. The expedition collected 10,030 km (5,416 nm) of multi-beam sonar data.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|title=U.S. Law of the Sea Cruise to map and sample the US Arctic Ocean margin|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/sites/default/files/publications/HEALY1202_FINAL_CRUISE%20REPORT.pdf|work=Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center, University of New Hampshire|accessdate=November 21, 2013|author2=Andrew Armstrong|page=24|date=September 28, 2012}}</ref> HEALY-1202 began in [[Barrow, Alaska]], reached a northernmost point of 83° 32’ N, 162° 36’ W, and culminated in [[Dutch Harbor, Alaska]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|title=U.S. Law of the Sea cruise to map and sample the US Arctic Ocean margin|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/sites/default/files/publications/HEALY1202_FINAL_CRUISE%20REPORT.pdf|work=Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center, University of New Hampshire|accessdate=November 21, 2013|author2=Andrew Armstrong|page=1}}</ref>
Prior to the ''Healy'' cruises, the foot of the slope of the US continental shelf was believed to lie at the margin of the Chukchi Plateau. The cruises revealed that the foot of the slope was significantly further north at 81° 15’ N and a depth of approximately 3,800 m<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|title=U.S. Law of the Sea Cruise to map and sample the US Arctic Ocean margin|url=http://ccom.unh.edu/sites/default/files/publications/HEALY1202_FINAL_CRUISE%20REPORT.pdf|work=Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center, University of New Hampshire|accessdate=November 21, 2013|author2=Andrew Armstrong|page=8|date=September 28, 2012}}</ref>–the boundary of the Northern Chukchi Borderland with the Nautilus Basin.<ref name=Baker/>
[[Image:Voyage of the USCGC Healy and the Chukchi cap.png|thumb|Voyage of the USCGC Healy and the Chukchi cap]]
In 2011 scientists aboard sea vessel, [[RV Marcus G. Langseth|''Marcus G. Langseth'']], ran tests to increase understanding of the geology, structure and history of the continental shelves running underwater off Asia and North America, and the Chukchi Borderland, an adjoining region of dramatic deep-sea plateaus and ridges some 800 miles from the North Pole. One test includes sending sound pulses to the seabed and reading the echoes.<ref>[http://blogs.ei.columbia.edu/2011/09/14/exploring-an-unknown-arctic-seabottom-no-ice-included/ blogs.ei.columbia.edu]</ref>

[[Image:Lowercurtis.jpg|thumb|right|Lower Curtis Glacier is a corrie glacier in the [[North Cascades]] in the State of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]]] A ''cirque glacier'' is formed in a [[cirque]], a bowl-shaped depression on the side of or near mountains. Snow and ice accumulation in corries often occurs as the result of [[avalanche|avalanching]] from higher surrounding slopes. If a cirque glacier advances far enough, it may become a valley glacier. Additionally, if a valley glacier retreats enough that it is within the cirque, it becomes a cirque glacier again.
In these depressions, [[snow]] persists through summer months, and becomes [[glacier]] ice. Snow may be situated on the [[leeward]] slope of a mountain, where it is sheltered from wind. Rock fall from above slopes also plays an important role in sheltering the snow and ice from sunlight. If enough rock falls onto the glacier, it may become a [[rock glacier]].
[[Randkluft]]s may form beneath corrie glaciers as open space between the ice and the bedrock, where meltwater can play a role in [[Deposition (geology)|deposition]] of the rock.
==Further reading== * Lewis, W.V. (1960) ''Norwegian Cirque Glaciers'', Royal Geographical Society Research Series 4
[[Category:Glaciology]] [[Category:Cirques]]
{{Glaciology-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=May 2018}} [[File:Cuba The Great War.jpg|242px|thumb|right|Cuba (yellow) in the Greater Antilles during World War 1.]] The [[Republic of Cuba]] had maintained neutrality during much of [[World War I]]. However this changed in 1917, after German submarine warfare resumed on February 1, 1917. On April 7, 1917, one day after the [[United States of America]] entered the war, '''Cuba declares war on Germany''' and began to support the Allied war effort. Cuba also declared war on [[Austria-Hungary]] later in the year on December 16.
A draft law was enacted and 25,000 soldiers were ready for shipment to [[France]] when the armistice intervened. A hospital unit of 100 Cuban doctors and nurses was equipped and sent to the [[Western Front (World War I)]].
==Background== [[Mario Garcia Menocal]] (December 17, 1866 - September 7, 1941) served as [[President of Cuba]] from 1913 until 1921. Supported by the USA and an economic boom, he maintained his office when World War I broke out. President [[Woodrow Wilson]] and the USA entered the war on April 6, 1917. With strong ties to its neighbours and put under preassure by New York Times reports of German [[U-boats]] resupplying in Cuba, the later followed suit an declared war on April 7.
==Entering World War I== [[File:Cuba declares war on Germany.jpg|217px|thumb|left|The Arizona Daily Star - Cuba declares war on Germany on Friday 7 April 1917.]]
[[File:Cuba declaration war original 1917.png|218px|thumb|right|Original Spanish newspaper in 1917.]]
Because of the total submarine warfare declared by Germany and the continued sinking of ships of different neutral nationalities on the American shores, [[Brazil]] and [[Cuba]] had sent angry protest to the Germans. President Menocal, encouraged by the United States` entry into the war, asked the congress of Cuba to declare war as well, enthusiastically stating that Cuba could not remain neutral. The Cuban senate unanimously passed a resolution that a state of war existed against Germany and the Cuban congress approved the declaration of war on April 7, 1917.
Thus Cuba was one of the few [[Latin American]] countries, along with [[Panama]], [[Bolivia]] and [[Uruguay]], who joined the [[Allies of World War I]]. Most countries in the region, including [[Mexico]], maintained their [[neutral country|neutral]] position.
==War effort on Cuba== After the declaration of war all German ships within [[Havana Harbor]] were [[seized]]. Likewise Cuban ports opened to Allied warships. Likewise, a bill was being drafted to authorize the offering of a contingent of 12,000 men to the United States.
Internal politics were strengthened by the declaration as liberals, who agreed with the move, decided to stop criticizing the government. In July 1917, the Menocal government suspended constitutional guarantees with the measure being claimed to be intended against German spies.
The Cuban government also agreed to the stationing of [[U.S. Marines]] on the island. However the Americans, afraid that this would undermine the national and international position of the Menocal government, announced that the goal of the intervention was to support the sugar harvest as major war contribution of Cuba, thus becoming known as [[Sugar Intervention]].
The [[Cuban Red Cross]] was also reorganized, established operations in Europe and supported the Allied forces on the [[Western Front (World War 1)|Western Front]].
==War on Austria-Hungary==
[[File:Cuban The Great War.png|217px|thumb|left|Cuban War Mission (left to right in photograph) to Washington Included Lieutenant Colonel Lezama, Alberto Carricarti and General Jose Marti.]]
The [[United States declaration of war on Austria-Hungary]] on December 7, 1917. [[Panama]] followed on December 10, 1917 and Cuba would do the same on December 16.
==Recognition of the Mexican government==
[[File:Cuba recognizes the government of Mexico.jpg|218px|thumb|right|On Thursday April 4, 1918, Havana and Mexico City exchanged ambassadors for a further Cuban-Mexican relation.]]
In the midst of the diplomatic crisis caused by the disappearance of the diplomatic baggage of Mexican Ambassador [[Isidro Fabela]], the government of Cuba officially acknowledged the constitutional Government of [[Venustiano Carranza]]. Federico Jimenez O'Farril presented a hand-written letter of the Cuban president to the Mexican President, in which he granted the recognition.
Despite the diplomatic act, the relationship between the two countries cooled due to the treatment of the Mexican travelers in Havana.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:World War I| ]] [[Category:History of Cuba| ]]
==Also See==
[[Cuba during World War II]]

[[File:Slumgullion Earthflow.jpg|thumb|Image of [[Slumgullion Earthflow]]]] An '''earthflow''' ('''earth flow''') is a downslope viscous flow of fine-grained materials that have been saturated with water and moves under the pull of [[gravity]]. It is an intermediate type of [[mass wasting]] that is between [[downhill creep]] and [[mudflow]]. The types of materials that are susceptible to earthflows are [[clay]], fine [[sand]] and [[silt]], and fine-grained [[pyroclastic]] material.<ref name=East>Easterbrook, D: “Surface Processes and Landforms”, page 78-79. Prentice-Hall, Inc, 1999</ref>
When the ground materials become saturated with enough water, they will start flowing ([[soil liquefaction]]). Its speed can range from being barely noticeable to rapid movement. The velocity of the flow is dictated by water content: the higher the water content is, the higher the velocity will be.<ref name=East/> Because of the dependency on water content for the velocity of the flow, it can take minutes or years for the materials to move down the slope.
== Features and behavior == Earthflows are just one type of [[mass movement]] that can occur on a hill slope. It has been recognized as its own type of movement since the early 20th century.<ref>Baum, R.L., and W.Z. Savage, and J. Wasowski.(2003) ''Mechanics of Earth Flows.'' Proceedings of the International Conference FLOWS. Sorrento, Italy. [http://ww.unina2.it/flows2003/flows2003/articoli/SAVAGE.pdf Mechanics of Earth Flows.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222080721/http://ww.unina2.it/flows2003/flows2003/articoli/SAVAGE.pdf |date=2015-12-22 }}</ref> Earthflows are one of the most [[fluid]] types of mass movements. Earthflows occur on heavily saturated slopes like [[mudflows]] or a [[debris flow]]. Though earthflows are a lot like mudflows, overall they are slower and are covered with solid material carried along by flow from within.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Physical Geography|last = Petersen|first = James|publisher = Cengage Learning|year = 2011|isbn = 111142750X|location = |pages = 441–443}}</ref> Earthflows are often made up of fine-grained materials so slopes consisting of [[clay]] and [[silt]] materials are more likely to create an earthflow.
As earthflows are usually water-dependent, the risk of one occurring is much higher in humid areas especially after a period of heavy rainfall or [[snowmelt]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title = Key Concepts in Geomorphology|last = Bierman|first = Paul|publisher = W.H. Freeman and Company Publishers|year = 2014|isbn = 1464152985|location = New York|pages = }}</ref> The high level of [[precipitation]], which saturates the ground and adds water to the slope content, increases the pore-water pressure and reduces the [[Shear strength|shearing strength]] of the material. As the slope becomes wet, the earthflow may start as a [[Creep (deformation)|creep]] downslope due to the clay or silt having less friction. As the material is increasingly more saturated, the slope will fail, which depends on [[slope stability]]. In earthflows, the slope does not fail along a clear shear plane and is instead more fluid as the material begins to move under the force of gravity as friction and slope stability is reduced.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Environmental Hydrology|last = Ward|first = Andy|publisher = CRC Press|year = 2003|isbn = 1566706165|location = |pages = }}</ref>
== Velocity == Earthflows vary in velocity of flow depending partly on the consistency of the flow for the speed of the entire movement, usually meaning how much water is in the material of the hill slope before the slope fails. Though water is often the key factor in slope failure, triggering an earthflow, there can also be dry granular flows made up of [[granular material]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url =http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2004/3072/pdf/fs2004-3072.pdf|title =Landslide Types and Processes|date =|accessdate =|website =USGS|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =no|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20160405030314/http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2004/3072/pdf/fs2004-3072.pdf|archivedate =2016-04-05|df =}}</ref> The speed also depends on the angle of slope as earthflows can happen on moderate or steep slopes.<ref name=":0" /> Because earthflows are usually water-dependent, they can take many years or just minutes to move a significant amount. An earthflow may affect as few as several square meters or up to several hectares in either time frame.
== Effects == Earthflows can have sudden impacts on the amount of sediment that is deposited into a river system, which can have effects on the life in and around the river itself. They can also cause damage to roads and constructions built near the slope. One of the best mitigation techniques to avoid serious earthflow and [[landslide]] damage is properly draining the slope of water, especially in places of high levels of precipitation.<ref name=":1" />
== Areas of risk == The areas most at risk for earthflows are: * Slopes that have been undercut or loaded with more sediment for human construction * Slopes that have been undercut by [[river]]s or stream beds * Areas that receive heavy rainfall or snowmelt * Hill slopes made up of clay, silt, or other fine-grained materials * Areas with limited vegetation on hill slopes * Areas with evidence of past earthflows
== See also == * [[Landslide mitigation]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://pubs.usgs.gov/bul/b2130/ Slumgullion earthflow, USGS Bulletin 2130], a [[National Natural Landmark]] in [[Colorado]], USA. * [http://blogs.agu.org/landslideblog/2015/04/17/russian-earthflow-1/ New landslide video: a fascinating and huge Russian earthflow] - American Geophysical Union, 17 April 2015
[[Category:Geological hazards]] [[Category:Soil mechanics]]
