{{for|the film|The Water Horse}} {{Infobox mythical creature | name = Water Horse | image = Gutt på hvit hest.jpg | caption = Portrait of a boy riding a ''nykk'' in the form of a water horse, by [[Theodor Kittelsen]] | Sub_Grouping = [[Lake monster]]
[[Sea Monster]]
[[Sea serpent]]
Lake serpent | AKA = Kelpie, Waterhorse | Country = | Region = [[Celtic nations]]
[[Scandinavia]] | Grouping = | Habitat = Water | First reported = 1700s | Last sighted = February 1934 (in [[Loch Ness]]) | Status = }} A '''water horse''' (or "waterhorse" in some folklore) is a [[mythical creature]], such as the [[Ceffyl Dŵr]], [[Capaill Uisce]], the [[bäckahäst]] and [[kelpie]]. ==Name origin== [[File:Hippokampos, Nordisk familjebok.png|thumb|The hippocamp (as seen in this sketch from [[Pompeii]]) is a water creature that has been referred to as a water horse.]] The term "water horse" was originally a name given to the [[kelpie]], a creature similar to the [[Hippocampus (mythology)|hippocamp]], which has the head, neck and mane of a normal [[horse]], legs like a horse, [[webbed feet]], and a long, two-lobed, [[whale]]-like tail. The term has also been used as a nickname for [[lake monsters]], particularly [[Ogopogo]] and [[Loch Ness Monster|Nessie]].{{r|Sarasota}} The name "kelpie" has often been a nickname for many other Scottish lake monsters, such as [[each uisge]] and [[Morag (lake monster)|Morag]] of [[Loch Morar]] and Lizzie of [[Loch Lochy]].{{cite web |title=Monsters Inc: Scottish lochs and their creatures |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-highlands-islands-21603269 |publisher=BBC News |access-date=23 July 2016 |mode=cs2}} Other names for these sea monsters include "seahorse" (not referring to the [[seahorse]] fish) and "hippocampus" (which is the [[genus]] name for seahorses). The usage of "water horse" or "kelpie" can often be a source of confusion; some consider the two terms to be synonymous, while others distinguish the water horse as a denizen of lochs and the kelpie of turbulent water such as rivers, fords, and waterfalls. Some authors call one creature of a certain place a kelpie while others call it a water horse. The name "[[water bull]]" has been used for either creature. [[File:Evariste-Vital Luminais - Fuite de Gradlon.jpg|thumb|Flight of King Gradlon: Morvarc'h, the magical steed of King Gradlon of [[Ys]]]] The [[Brittany|Breton]] King [[Gradlon]]'s magical "horse of the sea" [[Morvarc'h]] (whose name literally means "sea horse" in Breton) was said to have the ability to gallop upon the waves of the sea, in a similar fashion to the water horses of [[Cornish folklore|Cornish]] legend. ==Other lake monsters== The water horse has often become a basic description of other lake monsters such as the Canadian [[Lake Okanagan]] monster [[Ogopogo]] and the [[Lake Champlain]] monster [[Champ (cryptozoology)|Champ]]. [[Loch Morar]] is reputedly home to "[[Morag (loch monster)|Morag]]", a [[lake monster]] that has been portrayed as a water horse. ==Settings== Whilst most Scottish/Celtic [[folklore]] places the water horse in a [[loch]] (particularly a loch that is famous for a lake monster, such as [[Loch Ness]], [[Loch Morar]] or [[Loch Lomond]]), some [[Breton people|Breton]] and [[Cornish people|Cornish]] tales of water horses place them in the [[ocean]], making them [[sea monster]]s. Most Highland loch have some kind of water-horse tradition, although a study of 19th-century literature of the time showed that only about sixty lochs and lochans merited a mention out of the thousands of bodies of water in Scotland. The water horse that was reputed to inhabit Loch Ness gained the most mentions in Highland literature.{{sfnp|Watson|2011|ps=none}} ==Sightings== Water horse sightings were reported regularly during the 18th century, but it was not until the 19th century that sightings were recorded. * In 1846 Captain Christmas of the [[Danish Navy]] reported sighting "an enormous, long-necked beast pursuing a school of [[dolphins]]" somewhere between [[Iceland]] and the [[Faroe Islands]]. He described the creature as having a horse-like head and a neck as thick as a man's [[waist]] "moving gracefully like a [[swan]]'s". * On 6 August 1848 an officer of the [[Royal Navy]] corvette [[HMS Daedalus (1826)|HMS ''Daedalus'']] noticed an unusual looking animal swimming towards the ship. It was said to look similar to a [[sea serpent]] with a {{convert|4|ft|m|1|order=flip|adj=mid|-long}} neck. Its head was about {{convert|15|or|16|in|cm|0|abbr=on|order=flip}} long. It was reported to have no visible fins/flippers or tail, and it had what appeared to be a horsy mane on its neck with [[seaweed]] washed over its back. * In late 1883, two horse-headed beasts, one of them smaller than the other (suggesting or implying a [[juvenile (organism)|juvenile]]), were reported off the southern coast of [[Panama]]. The crew of the American [[whaler]] ''Hope On'' reported seeing a {{convert|20|ft|m|0|order=flip|adj=mid|-long}} creature submerge. It was brownish coloured with black speckles and four legs/flippers with a tail "that seemed to be divided into two parts" (implying the whale-like tail appearance) and all four limbs and tail were exposed when it reached the surface. A second creature that looked just like it only much smaller tagged along behind it. In the same year, a sighting of a similar looking creature occurred in the [[Bristol Channel]]. This creature was reported as leaving behind a greasy [[slug]]/[[snail]]-like trail. ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wpocAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ymUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7167,2800965&dq=as-water-horse+and+great+water+bull&hl=en |date=12 March 1967 |title=Loch Ness monster no laughing matter at Inverness |access-date=12 May 2014 |last=Anderson |first=Godfrey |newspaper=Sarasota Herald |mode=cs2}} }} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} *{{citation |title=The Water Horses of Loch Ness |last=Watson |first=Roland |year=2011 |isbn=1-4611-7819-3}}{{Self-published inline|date=May 2014}} {{refend}} {{Fairies}} [[Category:Celtic legendary creatures]] [[Category:Scandinavian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Mythological horses]] [[Category:Water spirits]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''δ''<sup>15</sup>N}} In [[geochemistry]], [[hydrology]], [[paleoclimatology]] and [[paleoceanography]] '''''δ''<sup>15</sup>N''' (pronounced "delta fifteen n") or '''delta-N-15''' is a measure of the ratio of the two [[stable isotope]]s of [[nitrogen]], [[Nitrogen-15|<sup>15</sup>N]]:[[Nitrogen-14|<sup>14</sup>N]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Katzenberg | first=MA | title=Biological Anthropology of the Human Skeleton | chapter=Chapter 13: Stable Isotope Analysis: A Tool for Studying Past Diet, Demography, and Life History | year=2008 | edition=2nd | isbn=978-0-471-79372-4 }}</ref>
==Formulas==
Two very similar expressions for {{delta|15|N}} are in wide use in [[hydrology]].<ref name="hed">{{cite article|last=Bedard-Haughn|first=A.|title=Tracing {{delta|15|N}} through landscapes: potential uses and precautions|journal=Journal of Hydrology|volume=272|pages=175-190|year=2003|bibcode=2003JHyd..272..175B|doi=10.1016/S0022-1694(02)00263-9}}</ref> Both have the form <math>1000\frac{s-a}a</math> ‰ (‰ = permil or parts per thousand) where ''s'' and ''a'' are the relative abundances of <sup>15</sup>N in respectively the sample and the atmosphere. The difference is whether the relative abundance is with respect to all the nitrogen, i.e. <sup>14</sup>N plus <sup>15</sup>N, or just to <sup>14</sup>N. Since the atmosphere is 99.6337% <sup>14</sup>N and 0.3663% <sup>15</sup>N, ''a'' is 0.003663 in the former case and 0.003663/0.996337 = 0.003676 in the latter. However ''s'' varies similarly; for example if in the sample <sup>15</sup>N is 0.385% and <sup>14</sup>N is 99.615%, ''s'' is 0.003850 in the former case and 0.00385/0.99615 = 0.003865 in the latter. The value of <math>1000\frac{s-a}a</math> is then 51.05‰ in the former case and 51.38‰ in the latter, an insignificant difference in practice given the typical range of -20 to 80 for {{delta|15|N}}.
==Applications==
One use of <sup>15</sup>N is as a tracer to determine the path taken by fertilizers applied to anything from pots to landscapes.<ref name="hed" /> Fertilizer enriched in <sup>15</sup>N to an extent significantly different from that prevailing in the soil (which may be different from the atmospheric standard ''a'') is applied at a point and other points are then monitored for variations in {{delta|15|N}}.
Another application is the assessment of human waste water discharge into bodies of water.<ref>http://longislandsoundstudy.net/2010/07/sediment-delta-15/</ref> The abundance of <sup>15</sup>N is greater in human waste water than in natural water sources. Hence {{delta|15|N}} in [[Benthic zone|benthic]] sediment gives an indication of the contribution of human waste to the total nitrogen in the sediment. Sediment cores analyzed for {{delta|15|N}} yield an historical record of such waste, with older samples at greater depths.
